They ought to know that translations will fail them in a test like that, and that the sensible course for them is to do their own work as they go along and to learn how to do any task assigned them.

4. Assign lessons which can be done within a reasonable time, without overtaxing your class. The translation habit is sometimes traceable to unreasonably long lessons. Even honest students feel under such circumstances that they cannot hope to do all the work required and so they have recourse to the inviting â€œtrot.'' No matter if the standard requirement does call for so much Latin, do what your class can do well, and with fair consideration for other departmentsâ€š and let the rest go undone. Make definite assignments in construction. Do not call for any and all sorts of constructions each day. Begin on one or two things in syntax, as has been 'repeatedly urged, and move on evenly, adding one thing at a time and leaving a construc- tion when it is learned.
